posts.name: Taylor
posts.cooked:
Hello FRC!  

I'm working on a personal project where I'd control a Kraken X60 motor using a Raspberry Pi. My goal is for an external application to communicate with a server on the Pi, which will then interact with the motor controller via Controller Area Network. However, this seems challenging based on what I've read.  

What would be the best way to achieve this? I've been researching USB to Controller Area Network adapters but haven't yet understood the complexities involved. I'm seeking advice from those with more experience.  

Thank you!

I believe this article from CTRE Cross The Road Electronics should have most of the information you're looking for. You'll also want to read this article on requirements to ensure you're using a supported setup, if you haven't already. Edit: disclaimer I have never used phoenix outside of FRC FIRST Robotics Competition.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Depending on what prices you find, you could either use a carnivore or other Linux socket-compatible USB adapter. I have had success with a Canable for non-FRC robotics.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: I’ve had success with a canable for non frc robotics. Same! They are usually out of stock when I look. This works for CAN 2.0 but I don’t know about Kraken with CAN FD. The CANivore however should work for CAN FD. I have not used the CANivore outside of FRC yet so can’t speak to that myself.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: The Jesscasday CANable 2.0 CANbus Transceiver converts CAN bus data into PCAN interfaces via USB, offering high-speed and accurate CAN data acquisition and analysis. It is designed for reliable performance and compatibility with CAN systems. Available at a price of $25.95.

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: Jesscasday CANable 2.0 CANbus Transceiver USB to CAN Protocol Analyzers CAN2.0 Serial Controller CANable Based on STM32G431C8T6 : Industrial & Scientific

posts.name: Taylor
posts.cooked: It looks like it would arrive a little late. Do you think this would work? Amazon.com: USB to CAN Module Type C Power Supply Converter Adapter for CAN 2.0A CAN 2.0B CAN FD Protocol Bus Analyzer V2.0 LED Indicator High Performance : Electronics

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: USB to CAN Module Type C Power Supply Converter Adapter for CAN 2.0A CAN 2.0B CAN FD Protocol Bus Analyzer V2.0 LED Indicator High Performance : Electronics

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Yeah that looks fine make sure to flash the newest firmware if you do get it.

posts.name: Ryan Radtke
posts.cooked: If you would like me to explain, how do you control motors with the cable? I’ve only been able to view the data and haven’t found anything related to controlling online.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Of note, PWM control is an option… depending on the need could be a lot simpler.

posts.name: Taylor
posts.cooked: I’ve been reading the same thing elsewhere. This is the first programming I’ve done with these systems, so I don’t actually know the pros and cons between the two. From what I understand, CAN is useful to get the feedback from the encoders and stuff, right?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Gotcha.

Short answer is that PWM communicates one thing, one direction. CAN communicates many things, both directions. It’s up to the motor and controller what all those things will be.

In the case of a Kraken, PWM control allows you to adjust the percentage of battery voltage applied to the windings.

With that context, this seems to be an X/Y problem.

You chose “Raspberry Pi” and “Kraken X60”. Why these choices?

Secondly, what’s your overall goal?

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Cross The Road Electronics has a lot of information about using Phoenix on a Pi and all the apt stuff. I’ve only used the CABLE for socket communication with a custom brushless controller, and the Linux side is in Python, just communicating with the socket can device.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: Depending on what you're doing, most cases require you to use the Phoenix motor control library and call functions similar to how you would in your regular FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) code but solely in C++. My first use case involved controlling two TalonSRX motor controllers with joystick inputs on a Jetson Nano; I created a regular C++ program incorporating those libraries. I plan to look for a sample code snippet later today. My old repository is no longer accessible, but I found an offline copy online. The example from [GitHub](https://github.com/CrossTheRoadElec/Phoenix5-Linux-Example/blob/master/example.cpp) serves as a good starting point, and I adapted it for my specific project, adjusting settings like CAN ID configuration, control modes, speed, and joystick input handling (initially through SDL, now using Bluetooth and app control).

posts.name: Taylor
posts.cooked:
I’m experiencing the XY problem, which is why I’m reaching out. I’ve chosen the Pi because the RoboRio is unavailable and offers better functionality. My objective is to create a compact motor controller using network communication via OSC or TCP. To achieve this, I’ll need to establish a webserver capable of controlling the motor.  

I selected the Kraken for its robustness and efficiency. Although mechanical integration will require time, it stands out as the optimal choice for my needs. My plan involves developing a Python program that interfaces with the GPIO, a webserver, and the motor. I intend to utilize limit switches and possibly a laser sensor. As a result, I may not need the CAN bus for feedback, relying instead on PWM signals, which the Pi should support. However, I lack sufficient knowledge to make definitive communication decisions between the Pi and Talon FX.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: The svelte application should perform a specific task, while the motor will be controlled using PWM. PWM will be much simpler to implement on the Pi.

posts.name: Taylor
posts.cooked: I can’t discuss many specifics, but it involves adjusting the height of something using a belt/pulley or a chain/sprocket system. I plan to connect buttons to the GPIO for up/down functionality and allow the Svelte app to use preset locations that I can create, update, and navigate to.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Do you need the "thing" at a specific height each time or can it be adjusted up or down?

posts.name: Taylor
posts.cooked: The laser distance sensor can be used for position without worrying about the encoders on the Kraken.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Would it be something that you could just use an ultrasonic distance sensor line-of-sight with? If that were the case, pwm would be as capable as needed.

posts.name: Taylor
posts.cooked: Yep. So it seems PWM is the correct path to take.

data.title: Control Kraken X60 With Raspberry Pi
data.fancy_title: Control Kraken X60 With Raspberry Pi

accepted_answer.excerpt: Just using the existing can wiring to a gpio that supports pwm, the kraken’s manual will tell you which cable is ground and which is pwm signal and something like https://pinout.xyz will tell you where to wire them on the pi
